utterances: Thanks a lot for having me.
And, first, the arrests of three men, two of them in Norway, one, I gather, based in Norway but vacationing in Germany, what have they been charged with?
Well, they've been charged with terrorism-related charges -plotting terrorism.
And, you know, officials have said that it's linked to al-Qaida.
Also, in Britain yesterday, a man named Abid Nasir(ph) was arrested and he was charged with being involved in some plot to blow up another shopping mall in England.
These cases are supposed to be connected to the Zazi case from the U.S.?
Correct.

What we're seeing is the New York subway plot, the shopping center plot in England, and now this Oslo plot, they're three legs of the stool, if you will, you know, different plots that al-Qaida's operational chiefs have been running against the United States and Europe.
A name that comes up in this story is that of Adnan al Subazuma(ph), Saudi-born, American-raised.
He was charged in Brooklyn yesterday, for allegedly plotting both the planned subway bombings, the Zazi case, and also the planned British shopping center bombing.
What do you know about Subazuma?
Well, Subazuma has alluded the FBI for years.
He's a most-wanted terrorist, there's a $5 million reward out for him.
And he appears to have taken on the mantle as the lead al-Qaida figure, planning these attacks against the, you foreign targets such as the United States, U.K., and Norway.
And one thing you've reported that at least the Norwegian case has in common with the American case is the kind of explosive.
In all three cases, what we're seeing is the explosive that was intended to be used was a peroxide bomb.
Peroxide bombs are very - they're small but they're powerful, they can be transported easily.
And in the New York case, they were talking about just putting them in a backpack and walking onto a crowded subway during rush hour.
In trying to sort through what is new or different or what's familiar about this case as it's now emerging, one thing that seems to be consistent with recent arrests in the U.S.
is that the men from Norway and in Britain, like those in America, weren't infiltrated in like the 9/11 bombers.
These are people who had long-established legal residence, if not citizenship, in these countries.
That's absolutely right.
And I think what you're seeing is it's getting harder and harder to penetrate borders in any country.
And certainly in the United States, we're seeing more U.S.
citizens taking up arms against the United States.
There's been a real rash of that.

The other thing that's very interesting is that these plots seem to show al-Qaida has become a lot more nimble than it was a decade ago when it was coordinating these very complicated attacks like 9/11.
These attacks we're seeing here, these plots don't require a whole lot of coordination.
It's a bunch of guys trying to get a recipe for a bomb and they pick their target and just go set it off.
More nimble might be the glass half full from al-Qaida's standpoint.
Smaller is another way of describing it.
Not colossal, you know, aircraft flying into skyscrapers.
Absolutely.
But you know what, what we saw on Christmas was that you don't need to be - as far as al-Qaida's concerned, you don't need to be successful to scare a lot of people.
But it's not just Clinton and her supporters fighting to get Florida delegates seated at the convention.
John Alismon(ph) is a DNC member from Florida who endorsed the presidential candidacy of Ohio Congressman Dennis Kucinich.
At Saturday's meeting he'll be presenting Florida's challenge to the DNC ruling that stripped the state of all its delegates.
A close reading of party rules, he says, shows that the DNC went too far.
Alismon says the rules allows the DNC to penalize a state by stripping just half of it delegates.
If the DNC exercised that option, he says, Democrats would not be in the mess they're in today.
On the Republican side, where they did do a 50 percent reduction for the Florida delegates, Florida knocked out Rudy Giuliani and Mitt Romney, and John McCain became the clear frontrunner.
Other states pick corn, but Florida picks presidents, and in this case Florida was denied that opportunity.
Members of the rules and bylaws committee and DNC staff are leaning toward that solution, restoring half the state's delegates, and it's an approach the Obama campaign supports.
But it raises another question.
How would the delegates be divided?
Depending upon the formula used, Clinton could pick up anywhere between six and 19 delegates; in any case still not enough to catch Obama.
That could be one reason why Clinton has been calling for the DNC to seat not just half but all 211 of Florida's delegates.
And she's not the only one.
Florida's Senate Minority Leader Steve Geller agrees.
Geller filed a lawsuit in federal court saying that for Floridians a half a loaf solution just won't work.
There is incredible, incredible anger on the streets at the Democratic clubs, at the condos that I speak to, over the fact that our delegates haven't been fully seated.
I think the only way that we will be competitive in November is if they seat our delegates.
And here's something else: Saturday's meeting of the DNC rules and bylaws committee may not resolve the dispute after all.

The Clinton campaign has left open the possibility that it may appeal an unfavorable decision to the DNC credentials committee later this summer, which means that this fight may not be resolved until the party's convention in August.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
And as David mentioned, more Americans bought tickets to see the matches at the World Cup than any other visiting nationality.
The popularity of the game is growing at such a fast rate in the U.S.
that it will soon be one of soccer's biggest markets.
It's one of the many statistics in a 2010 ""World Cup and Economics"" report published by Goldman Sachs.
Andrew Swift is a researcher for Foreign Policy magazine and a writer for its Passport blog.
He's been digging through that report, and he joins me to talk about it.
Thanks for coming in.
Thanks for having me.
First of all, why does Goldman Sachs put out a World Cup analysis and index?
Maybe it's to get some good press.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, they probably need it.
They've had some troubles lately, so maybe putting out a football report on the World Cup is a way for people to get another look at them.
Okay, fine.

So they analyze the economies and the political situations in each country, and I gather there is a correlation between a country's productivity and their ranking according to FIFA, the football - International Football Association.
Can you explain that?
Yeah, Goldman uses something called GES, which is Growth Environment Scores, which is a roundup of factors from political, economic and social.
It's like rule of law, corruption, debt, and then social factors like computers and mobile phones.
They found, interestingly enough, that the - a GES score and FIFA ranking itself is not necessarily correlative.
Right.
But the improvement over the last four years and GES score and FIFA ranking is.
And this is - trend is especially noticeable among developing countries.
So, like, as Brazil becomes more economically powerful, its FIFA ranking goes up anyway?
Brazil and Argentina are sort of the outliers.
Right, because they're good and...
Yeah, exactly.
They've been good for so long, and their GES scores are not necessarily a proper indicator of their skill level.
But - so what's a good example?
Algeria, for example, is the one they listed.
Algeria did not qualify for the 2006 finals in Germany.
Did this year, they're in the group with England, United States and Slovenia.
And they - Algeria was the country that posts the highest improvement in both the GES score and FIFA ranking over the last four years.
Economy is getting better, their political situation is getting better.
Yeah.
Goldman attributed this, you know, to maybe better infrastructure or funding facilities, you know, for football leagues.
What I found quite astonishing about this report is the importance of the United States to the world soccer market.
Can you explain why that is?
Well, I'm part of a generation that grew up millions and millions of kids playing soccer, you know, boys and girls.
(Unintelligible) leagues.
Yeah, exactly.
Granted, 8-year-olds playing soccer is not particularly organized.
It's really a bunch of kids just running around chasing the ball.
Yeah.
But I think that familiarity is starting to breed genuine interest in the game globally.
24.5 million Americans play some sort of soccer, and that's the second highest number in the world behind China.
